I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Country  Strategy  and  Program  Update  (CSPU)  2004–2006  notes  that  poor 
governance and ineffective public sector management are the main development problems 
confronting  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG).1  A  country  governance  assessment,  conducted  in 
October 2002, highlighted the pervasive and widespread corruption and absence of a culture of 
compliance and transparency in the public service. During the visit, members of the Permanent 
Parliamentary Accounts Committee (PAC) inquired whether the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
could assist with institutional and capacity building, given the PAC's lack of technical knowledge 
and inadequate resources to actively play its role in improving accountability of the executive 
government and senior public servants. A Fact-Finding Mission visited PNG from 24 to 28 May 
2004 to discuss the work undertaken by the PAC to date, and perceptions of its efficiency and 
effectiveness by senior public officials, civil society, and development partners. Representatives 
from the Prime Minister's Office, Ministry of Finance and Treasury, development partners, and 
civil society emphasized the importance of the PAC, and strongly supported the proposed 
technical assistance (TA). During a follow-up visit in July 2004, the chairman of the PAC 
reiterated his support of the main thrust of the TA. 
 
2.  The TA complements initiatives by the Government, development partners, and ADB to 
strengthen good governance, in particular the public expenditure review and rationalization 
(PERR) process. A PERR review mission in May 2004 noted that while there has been progress 
in restoring the integrity of the budget systems and institutions, further attention has to be given 
to  improving  accountability  mechanisms  and  oversight  institutions.  The  PERR  action  plan 
includes a project on strengthening fiscal and governance oversight, which will provide a focal 
point for the Government to coordinate activities and achieve synergy of various aid agency and 
Government initiatives. The ongoing ADB-financed Public Service Program2 is assisting with 
wide-ranging public sector reform, including improved management of the public service and 
delivery of basic services, and building institutional capacity in the Auditor General's Office 
(AGO). The TA will build on and strengthen these initiatives. The TA's goals, purpose, and 
scope are summarized in the TA framework (Appendix 1).3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Since its reconstitution after the 2002 elections, the PAC has been active in conducting 
hearings into public agencies' compliance with financial rules and regulations, using the Auditor 
General’s reports to Parliament. The hearings have received widespread publicity and public 
support.  Several  members  of  the  PAC  are  strong  champions  of  reform  and  advocates  of 
transparent and accountable government. However, there are concerns that the inadequate 
understanding of the PAC members of their own mandate and scope of activities, the lack of 
detailed  PAC  procedures  to  ensure  transparency  of  its  own  process  and  decisions,  and 
inadequate resources to support its research and activities may undermine the committee’s 
credibility over time.         
 
4.  The functions of the PAC, set out in the constitution and under the Public Finance Act, 
are to examine and report to Parliament on public accounts, and on the control of and on 
transactions  with  or  concerning  public  monies  and  property.  The  PAC  acts  on  matters

recommended by the Auditor General and can subpoena witnesses and take evidence under 
oath. Because the AGO is not seen as competent or adequately resourced to carry out its 
mandate in a timely and comprehensive manner, the PAC is constrained in its efforts to hold 
public officials accountable. For instance, as the AGO has a backlog of audits and reports to 
Parliament usually 2–3 years (and longer) behind, actions based on such reports often do not 
lead to effective sanctions as these officials may have moved on or evidence has been lost or 
both. Consequently, PAC members have sometimes focused on more current issues, which 
have neither been reported to Parliament nor thoroughly researched. During the Fact-Finding 
Mission, a senior public servant, while strongly supporting the work of the PAC, expressed 
concerns that the PAC may thereby unintentionally become subject of legal disputes. 
 
5.  Currently  there  is  limited  exchange  of  information  and  communication  between  the 
Government and the PAC. The PAC does not always keep Government informed of its hearings 
nor of the subject matter considered in hearings. There is also no formal process for the PAC to 
monitor follow-up actions by agencies to implement its recommendations. An efficient interface 
between the PAC, central agencies, and the AGO is important to enhance the effectiveness of 
the PAC and, ultimately, public sector agencies. 
 
6.  The media in PNG has been very active in exposing cases of corruption. Several civil 
society organizations, such as the Community Coalition Against Corruption and Transparency 
International  PNG  section,  have  been  instrumental  in  raising  public  awareness  of  issues 
pertaining to corruption. However, outreach beyond the capital district and to the communities 
most affected has been limited (footnote 1). 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
7.  The  overall  objective of  the  TA  is  improved  accountability  and  transparency of  the 
executive government. The TA aims to assist the PAC to become more active and effective in 
exposing and following up cases of corruption and maladministration.  
 
8.  The TA will have the following outputs: 
 
(i)  Within the first 3 months of TA inception, a report will be produced containing (a) 
good  practices  of  PAC  mandates  and  activities  in  other  countries;  (b)  an 
assessment of the current legislative mandate of the PAC, and its weaknesses 
and  strengths  including  clarification  of  its  oversight  role  in  appointing  and 
monitoring  the  performance  of  the  auditor  general  and  the  AGO;  and  (c) 
recommendations  on  strengthening  the  terms  of  reference  and  legislative 
framework. The report will also include an annual and 3–years' work program 
together with the necessary budget allocations. 
(ii)  Based on the assessments, a manual will be produced outlining procedures for 
the PAC's hearings and special enquiries as well as a code of conduct. Seminars 
will  be  conducted  for  various  target  audiences  to  familiarize  Members  of 
Parliament  and  the  PAC,  relevant  government  officials,  and  senior  public 
servants as well as civil society with the clearly defined PAC terms of reference 
and scope of activities, and code of conduct. 
(iii)  The capacity of PAC staff and staff on attachment or seconded from the AGO to 
investigate, analyze and follow up cases brought to the attention of the PAC will 
be strengthened through on-the-job training and learning-by-doing.

3
(iv)  Formal communication channels between the PAC, other watchdog institutions, 
and relevant central agencies will have been institutionalized by the end of the 
TA.   
(v)  At least two special investigations on specific financial governance matters will 
be  conducted  with  recommendations  on  follow-up  actions  and  improvement 
initiatives. 
(vi)  Awareness among various stakeholders of PAC's role will be enhanced and civil 
society can constructively and actively engage with the PAC. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA will build on synergies, and coordinate all its activities with the ongoing PERR 
process, particularly the PERR project on improving fiscal and governance oversight, and with 
all other related governance initiatives by the Government, development partners, and ADB 
projects.  
 
10.  The TA will begin with developing terms of reference, code of conduct, and a manual of 
PAC procedures. The material will be used to guide the drafting of the Parliamentary Accounts 
Committee Act, currently planned for end–2004. In addition, a report with a work program and 
budget  will  be  produced.  The  development  of  the  annual  PAC  work  program  will  include 
identifying  at  least  two  topics  or  cases  for  investigations  on  specific  financial  governance 
matters relevant to the current governance environment in the country. Such studies can, for 
instance, look at the appropriateness and effectiveness of the existing intergovernmental fiscal 
relationship, financial management capacity of provinces and districts, and accountability of 
boards of directors and chief executives of government-owned enterprises to the Executive and 
Parliament. The process will involve consultation with Members of Parliament, the AGO, and 
representatives of Government and civil society. 
 
11.  Seminars will be conducted for Members of Parliament and the PAC, ministers, senior 
public servants, and civil society including community groups. The training courses aim to (i) 
familiarize Members of Parliament with the scope of the mandate of the PAC and its procedures 
manual, and (ii) raise awareness of the mandate of the PAC, among relevant central agencies 
and civil society. The seminars will use local facilitators, including domestic nongovernment 
organizations. 
 
12.  Special investigative studies will be conducted in close cooperation with and input from 
civil society organizations. During the process, particular attention will be paid to transfer of 
skills in investigative research, especially to media organizations. 
 
13.  A good practice interface mechanism between the PAC and relevant central agencies 
will be developed. The process will look at formalizing communication channels and methods to 
follow up actions, and for reporting back. 
 
14.  The PAC will be assisted in developing and implementing a communication strategy, 
including  a  plan  to  raise  awareness  of  the  PAC’s  mandate  and  functions  among 
parliamentarians, public servants, and the community in general. 
 
15.  The  lessons  learned  from  the  TA  will  be  disseminated  to  other  PACs  in  Pacific 
developing member countries as good practice to be considered in their effort to improve 
performance and effectiveness.

4  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $630,000 equivalent, comprising $409,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $221,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  provide  $500,000 
equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $91,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost on a grant basis, of which $300,000 will be financed by ADB's TA funding 
program and $200,000 by the Government of Australia. The Government of PNG will finance 
the remaining $130,000 equivalent of the local currency costs for counterpart staff salaries, 
office accommodation, and transport. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The PAC will be the Executing Agency of the TA. At the start of implementation one lead 
consultant (international) will be recruited for 6 person-months on an intermittent basis. One 
domestic  consultant  will  be  engaged  for  3  person-months  to  develop  and  implement  a 
communication strategy. Two international consultants will be recruited for 15 person-months on 
an intermittent basis during the course of the TA. Outline terms of reference for the consultants 
are in Appendix 3. During the first 2 months of implementation, the lead consultant will, in close 
consultation  with  the  PAC,  develop  detailed  terms  of  reference  for  the  two  international 
consultants. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic 
consultants. The consultants will be engaged individually.  
 
18.  The TA will allow for the purchase of up to three computers, along with printers and 
standard software to be allocated to the office of the PAC. The equipment will be purchased in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement and procedures acceptable to ADB. 
 
19.  The TA will be executed over 26 months, and is expected to start in November 2004 and 
be completed by December 2006. Implementation will be based on a process approach, with 
flexibility maintained to meet adjusting priorities and needs. 
 
20.  Overall reporting responsibilities are with the lead consultant. Within 1 month of TA 
inception, the lead consultant will submit an inception report outlining the work program for the 
TA. After 3 months, an initial report containing (a) good practices of PAC mandates, (b) an 
assessment  of  the  current  legislative  mandate  of  the  PAC,  and  (c)  recommendations  on 
strengthening the terms of reference and legislative framework will be submitted. The report will 
include an annual and a 3–years' work program for the PAC together with the necessary budget 
allocations as well as details of the consultative process used. Subsequent progress reports will 
be submitted after 9 months and 15 months of TA inception, with input from the specialist 
consultants. The final report containing lessons learned will be produced at the end of TA 
implementation. Implementation will be based on a process approach, with flexibility maintained 
to meet adjusting priorities and needs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia, and (ii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of Papua New

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Lead Consultant (international, 6 person-months) 
 
1.  The international consultant will be working intermittently over the period of the technical 
assistance (TA). The first assignment will be for at least 3 months, while the subsequent country 
visits will be determined during the first few weeks of TA implementation. 
 
2.  Experience and qualifications required of the consultant are as follows: 
 
(i)   tertiary-level  qualification  in  public  administration,  finance,  economics,  or  a 
related field; 
 
(ii)  extensive  experience  in  working  with  public  accounts  committees  in  similar 
environments; 
 
(iii)  excellent communication and interpersonal skills; and 
 
(iv)  experience in providing training to various audiences, including senior public 
sector officials and parliamentarians. 
 
3.  The consultant's responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Assess  good  practices  of  the  Parliamentary  Accounts  Committee  (PAC) 
mandates and activities in similar country contexts, and the current legislative 
mandate of the PAC, its weaknesses and strengths.  
 
(ii)  Based on the assessment and in consultation with Members of Parliament, the 
PAC,  the  Auditor  General's  Office  (AGO),  government  and  civil  society 
representatives make recommendations on strengthening the terms of reference 
and the legal framework. The recommendations should also clarify the oversight 
functions of the committee in appointing and monitoring the Auditor General and 
the AGO. 
 
(iii)  In consultation with the PAC, develop a code of conduct and procedures manual 
for PAC members.  
 
(iv)  Based on the above assessment, code of conduct, and procedures manual, 
assist the PAC in conducting seminars for various target audiences. 
 
(v)  Develop,  in  consultation  with  members  of  the  PAC  and  other  relevant 
stakeholders, an annual and 3-years' work program including required budget 
allocations. 
 
(vi)  In developing the annual work program, identify two or three topics or cases for 
investigations on specific financial governance matters relevant to the current 
governance environment in the country. Such studies could, for instance, look at 
the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  the  existing  intergovernmental  fiscal 
relationship and financial management capacity of provinces and districts, and 
accountability of boards of directors and chief executives of government-owned

enterprises  to  the  Executive  and  Parliament.  The  process  will  involve 
consultation  with  Members  of  Parliament,  the  AGO,  and  representatives  of 
Government and civil society. 
 
(vii)   Discuss  with the chairperson of the PAC and PAC members the detailed terms 
of reference for the two additional international consultants (total of 15 person-
months) and refine the terms of reference for consulting requirements. Where 
possible and where the sensitivity of the situation allows, preference should be 
given to hiring domestic consultants.  
 
(viii)  Develop  a  good  practice  interface  between  the  PAC  and  relevant  central 
agencies.  In consultation with the PAC and government agencies, assess the 
possibilities of formalizing communication channels and methods to follow up 
actions and for reporting back to Parliament. Provide guidance and training to 
institutionalize the process. 
 
(ix)   Cooperate closely with domestic consultants or nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs) on a communication strategy for the PAC. 
 
(x)   Assist in disseminating lessons learned from the TA to other PACs in Pacific 
developing member countries (PDMCs). 
 
4.  For  all  project  activities,  the  consultant  will  consider  building  on  the  synergies  and 
coordinate with the ongoing public expenditure review and rationalization (PERR) process, 
particularly the PERR project on improving fiscal and governance oversight, and with all other 
related  governance  initiatives  by  the  Government,  development  partners,  and  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) projects.  
 
5.  The consultant will be responsible for the following reports: 
 
(i)  within 1 month of TA commencement, an inception report outlining the work 
program for the TA;  
 
(ii)  after 3 months of TA inception, an initial report containing (a) good practices of 
PAC mandates; (b) an assessment of the current legislative mandate of the PAC; 
and (c) recommendations on strengthening the terms of reference and legislative 
framework. The report will include an annual and a 3-years' work program for the 
PAC together with the necessary budget allocations as well as details of the 
consultative process used;  
 
(iii)  subsequent progress reports to be submitted after 9 months and 15 months of 
TA inception; and 
 
(iv)  the final report containing lessons learned at the end of TA implementation. The 
final report should contain recommendations on how to extend activities to other 
PACs in PDMCs.

B.  Two International Consultants (total 15 person-months) 
 
6.  The two consultants will be engaged for a total of 15 person-months on an intermittent 
basis. The detailed terms of reference will be determined and developed by the lead consultant 
during the first 2 months of TA implementation upon consultation with the PAC and based on 
the needs determined during the development of the work program for the PAC. 
 
 
7.  Experience and qualifications required of the two consultants will be as follows: 
 
(i)   tertiary-level qualification in public administration, law, finance, economics or a 
related field; 
 
(ii)  excellent communication and interpersonal skills; and 
 
(iii)  experience in providing training to various audiences, including senior public 
sector officials and parliamentarians. 
 
8.  The consultants' responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the lead consultant in implementing the annual work program of the PAC. 
 
(ii)  Assist the lead consultant in conducting training for the various stakeholders and 
training workshops and on-the-job training as required. 
 
(iii)  Provide  input  into  the  special  investigative  studies  on  specific  financial 
governance  matters  relevant  to  the  current  governance  environment  in  the 
country. 
 
(iv)  Cooperate  closely  with  domestic  consultants  or  NGOs  on  a  communication 
strategy for PAC. 
 
(v)   Assist in disseminating lessons learned from the TA to other PACs in PDMCs. 
 
(vi)  Assist the lead consultant in the overall TA reporting requirements.  
 
 
C.  Domestic Consultant - Communication Strategy for PAC (3 person-months) 
 
9.  The domestic consultant will work closely with the international consultants and work on 
an intermittent basis. 
 
10.  The consultant should have the following background: 
 
(i)  extensive understanding of the governance environment in PNG; 
 
(ii)   experience  in  community  outreach  activities  relating  to  governance  and 
corruption issues; and 
 
(iii)  fluency in Pidgin English and English.

(i)   Assist  the  PAC  in  developing  a  communication  strategy,  including  an

(ii)  Support the PAC in delivery of the communication strategy by developing and 
organizing awareness workshops or publicity using various media.
